name: The Family & Youth Institute
mission: Redefining the narrative on Muslim mental health and well-being and championing a world where individuals, families, and communities are empowered and flourishing.
theoryOfChange: The Family & Youth Institute explicitly states, 'the fyi's theory of change. How We Do It.' on their research page. They describe their approach as a 'community-based participatory research approach' that ensures projects are 'grounded in community spirit and collaboration' and 'bridging community, research, and practice.' Their mission is to strengthen and empower individuals, families, and communities through research and education, focusing on Muslim Americans' well-being through 'community-centered research, solution-seeking, and education' to promote mental health and well-being.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or program and highlight humanitarian dimensions of your work

judge_issues.message: BBB name 'Ackerman Institute For The Family' may not match 'The Family & Youth Institute' (similarity: 67%)

score_details.score_summary: THE FAMILY AND YOUTH INSTITUTE earns 51/100 due to good alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied). Evidence score may reflect limited reporting capacity, not program weakness.

all_citations.claim: The FYI focuses on Mental Health Research, Community Education, and Aging with Dignity projects.
The organization reported total revenue of $850,837, a program expense ratio of 83.6%, and fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised.
The organization is zakat-eligible and maintains a specific zakat policy.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The FYI demonstrates strong financial health and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by low data confidence and a capacity-building model that is harder to measure for direct impact.
areas_for_improvement: Limited data confidence and third-party verification of program outcomes
Niche focus on capacity building which may result in less direct beneficiary impact data

dimension_explanations.alignment: With a 29/50 alignment score, the charity offers a medium fit for donors interested in mental health advocacy and youth development [1]. It is verified as zakat-eligible, allowing Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through specific institutional policies [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization allocates 83.6% of its expenses toward its programs, including mental health research and community education [2]. While it holds 23.6 months of working capital, the impact score of 27/50 reflects a capacity-building approach where cost-per-beneficiary data is not currently available [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to strengthening families and promoting positive youth development through evidence-based mental health initiatives.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 83.6%, indicating a strong focus on direct service and research
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with only $0.09 spent to raise every $1
Robust financial stability with 23.6 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: The FYI focuses on community empowerment through its Mental Health Research, Community Education, and Aging with Dignity projects [1]. During the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $850,837 and maintains a zakat-eligible status for qualifying donations [2][4].

bbb_assessment.summary: This organization has not yet been reviewed by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="13">limited board independence</cite> and a lack of <cite id="14">external impact evaluations</cite>.

confidence.notes: Financial efficiency is high, but governance and transparency metrics are limited.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is strong for donors seeking <cite id="5">zakat-eligible research</cite> in an <cite id="18">underserved advocacy and mental health space</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be further improved by <cite id="19">adding a dedicated zakat page</cite> that details specific asnaf-eligible programs.

credibility.explanation: Credibility is established through a <cite id="1">20-year track record</cite> and recognition in <cite id="16">national newspapers and the White House</cite>. However, <cite id="15">data confidence remains low</cite> because the charity lacks a Candid seal and a full Charity Navigator rating.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should <cite id="17">expand its board size</cite> and pursue a Candid Seal of Transparency.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by an <cite id="6">83.6% program ratio</cite> and a <cite id="10">clear theory of change</cite>. The organization focuses on capacity building, which is a high-leverage but harder-to-measure intervention.
impact.improvement: The FYI could improve its impact score by <cite id="14">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary counts</cite> to enable cost-per-outcome analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Documented Theory of Change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct implementation of research and education

rich_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to strengthening families and promoting positive youth development through evidence-based mental health initiatives.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value intellectual and research-based foundations for community health and want to support zakat-eligible mental health advocacy.
donor_motivations: Want to address the root causes of family instability in the Muslim community
Value evidence-based approaches to youth development
Prefer supporting specialized research over direct emergency relief
Seek to fulfill zakat through educational and community empowerment (fisabilillah)
giving_considerations: Impact is long-term and academic rather than immediate and tangible
The organization is small and relies on a lean governance structure
Financial stability is high, but external transparency data is limited
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-volume direct service metrics (e.g., meals served) or those who require large, independent boards for governance assurance.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear theory of change and high programmatic spending, but <cite id="14">lacks external impact evaluations</cite>.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The FYI uses research to create educational tools that empower community leaders and families, leading to improved mental health outcomes.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that mental health interventions are culturally appropriate and effective for the target population.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="3">revenue of $850,837</cite> and a niche focus, the organization has significant room to scale its research staff and geographic reach.

peer_comparison.differentiator: The FYI maintains a <cite id="6">higher program ratio (83.6%)</cite> than the <cite id="9">peer median of 81.5%</cite>.
similar_orgs: Institute for Social Policy and Understanding

similar_organizations.differentiator: Larger scale and broader policy focus

similar_organizations.differentiator: Specific focus on racism and policy

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="6">83.6% of its total expenses</cite> toward research and education programs, exceeding the <cite id="9">peer median of 81.5%</cite>.
The FYI demonstrates high fiscal discipline, requiring only <cite id="7">$0.09 in expenses</cite> for every dollar of public support raised.
The charity maintains <cite id="8">23.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a robust buffer against economic volatility.

strengths_deep_dive: The FYI's strength lies in its specialized focus on the intersection of mental health and American Muslim identity. By maintaining a <cite id="10">documented theory of change</cite>, the organization ensures that its research on youth development and marriage support is actionable. Its financial health is notable for an organization of its size, with <cite id="11">total assets of $2,068,120</cite> and very low <cite id="12">liabilities of only $50,471</cite>, allowing it to focus on long-term research projects without immediate funding pressure.
rich_narrative.summary: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization that has been <cite id="1">operating since 2006</cite> to strengthen families and promote positive youth development. The organization focuses on community empowerment through its <cite id="2">Mental Health Research, Community Education, and Aging with Dignity projects</cite>. During the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a <cite id="3">total revenue of $850,837</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="4">contributions totaling $806,832</cite>. The FYI distinguishes itself by translating academic research into practical resources for the Muslim community, maintaining a <cite id="5">zakat-eligible status</cite> for its research and educational initiatives under the category of fisabilillah. Its financial model is characterized by high efficiency, dedicating a <cite id="6">program expense ratio of 83.6%</cite> to its core mission. This lean operational structure is further evidenced by its fundraising efficiency, spending only <cite id="7">$0.09 to raise every $1</cite>. While the organization is smaller in scale than national advocacy groups, it maintains significant financial stability with <cite id="8">23.6 months of working capital</cite> held in working capital, ensuring long-term sustainability for its research cycles.
